comment_text.mn19:1.1: This discourse shows that a meditator must abandon unwholesome thought then wholesome thought before entering absorption. It is one of several discourses that give detailed instructions on dealing with thought in meditation (eg. MN 18, MN 20, AN 3.101). While meditation existed before the Buddha, we do not find this kind of practical advice on how to go about it.
comment_text.mn19:2.1: This period of meditative development must have taken place after giving up self-mortification practices. MN 36:34.1 says that at this point, after restoring his strength by eating solid food, he developed the absorptions, giving the impression that this happened immediately. However, the current sutta, supported by passages such as MN 128:16.2, shows that this took some time, although it is not clear how long.
comment_text.mn19:2.3: By analyzing thoughts (vitakka), he is consciously developing the second factor of the noble eightfold path, right thought (sammāsaṅkappa). In this context, vitakka and saṅkappa are synonyms.
comment_text.mn19:3.3: First one knows the thought, understanding it in terms of the framework.
comment_text.mn19:3.4: Then one reflects on the causal outcome of the thought.
comment_text.mn19:3.5: Thoughts are eradicated not by force or judgment, but by reflective wisdom.
comment_text.mn19:4-5.1: The difference between “malice” (or “ill will”, byāpāda) and “cruelty” (vihiṁsā) is subtle; they are the respective opposites of “love” (mettā) and “compassion” (karuṇā). Mettā wishes well simply and without qualification, just as “malice” wishes ill. But karuṇa takes pleasure in the alleviation of pain, while vihiṁsā takes pleasure in inflicting pain.
comment_text.mn19:6.1: This is a key principle underlying Buddhist meditation.
comment_text.mn19:7.1: Compare AN 3.101, where the Buddha illustrates the same point with a simile of smelting gold.
comment_text.mn19:7.4: At this point, a meditator guards against unwholesome thoughts, gently and persistently.
comment_text.mn19:8.7: Meditators often wish to reach a state free of thought, but thought is a natural and essential function of the mind and wholesome habits of thought are a part of the eightfold path.
comment_text.mn19:8.10: Even good thought has a limit as the mind is still active. | Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.4.21 enjoins the contemplative not to think too much, as it is fatiguing to speech.
comment_text.mn19:8.11: As the sutta later makes clear, this means that he entered absorption. The process described here extends over a period of time during which these different factors arose, rather than a single meditation sitting.
comment_text.mn19:12.4: Compare MN 140:20.2 and AN 3.102:2.1, where, when smelting is going well, the goldsmith merely observes with equanimity.
comment_text.mn19:13.1: This passage, which describes the process of entering absorption, is here shown to be the opposite of the previous situation where the mind was continuing to think even wholesome thoughts.
comment_text.mn19:14.1: The first absorption still has vitakka, which above was rendered “thought” since it was clearly a verbal process. Jhāna is, however, a state of “higher mind” where all mental processes are elevated. Pleasure is no longer the coarse stimulus of the senses, seclusion is no longer just being physically isolated, rapture is no longer exciting. And vitakka is no longer the activity of verbalizing thought, as the burden of the sutta is to show that even wholesome thought prevents absorption. Rather, it is explained as a subtle process of placing the mind and keeping it in place (as defined at MN 117:14.2). The English word “thought” in the sense “to bring something to mind” might be elastic enough to cover this sense, but it is apt to be misleading. | The late canonical Peṭakopadesa has an interesting analysis that precedes the commentarial Theravadin understanding of this point (Pe 7).
comment_text.mn19:18.2: The text is elided in the Pali, but clearly is meant to be understood in full per MN 4:27.2.

root_text.mn19:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn19:2.1: “Pubbeva me, bhikkhave, sambodhā anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato etadahosi:
root_text.mn19:2.2: ‘yannūnāhaṁ dvidhā katvā dvidhā katvā vitakke vihareyyan’ti.
root_text.mn19:2.3: So kho ahaṁ, bhikkhave, yo cāyaṁ kāmavitakko yo ca byāpādavitakko yo ca vihiṁsāvitakko—
root_text.mn19:2.5: yo cāyaṁ nekkhammavitakko yo ca abyāpādavitakko yo ca avihiṁsāvitakko—
root_text.mn19:3.1: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato uppajjati kāmavitakko.
root_text.mn19:3.4: So ca kho attabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati, parabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati, ubhayabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati, paññānirodhiko vighātapakkhiko anibbānasaṁvattaniko’.
root_text.mn19:3.5: ‘Attabyābādhāya saṁvattatī’tipi me, bhikkhave, paṭisañcikkhato abbhatthaṁ gacchati;
root_text.mn19:3.6: ‘parabyābādhāya saṁvattatī’tipi me, bhikkhave, paṭisañcikkhato abbhatthaṁ gacchati;
root_text.mn19:3.7: ‘ubhayabyābādhāya saṁvattatī’tipi me, bhikkhave, paṭisañcikkhato abbhatthaṁ gacchati;
root_text.mn19:3.8: ‘paññānirodhiko vighātapakkhiko anibbānasaṁvattaniko’tipi me, bhikkhave, paṭisañcikkhato abbhatthaṁ gacchati.
root_text.mn19:3.9: So kho ahaṁ, bhikkhave, uppannuppannaṁ kāmavitakkaṁ pajahameva vinodameva byantameva naṁ akāsiṁ.
root_text.mn19:4-5.1: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato uppajjati byāpādavitakko …pe…
root_text.mn19:4-5.5: So ca kho attabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati, parabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati, ubhayabyābādhāyapi saṁvattati, paññānirodhiko vighātapakkhiko anibbānasaṁvattaniko’.
root_text.mn19:4-5.6: ‘Attabyābādhāya saṁvattatī’tipi me, bhikkhave, paṭisañcikkhato abbhatthaṁ gacchati;
root_text.mn19:4-5.7: ‘parabyābādhāya saṁvattatī’tipi me, bhikkhave, paṭisañcikkhato abbhatthaṁ gacchati;
root_text.mn19:4-5.8: ‘ubhayabyābādhāya saṁvattatī’tipi me, bhikkhave, paṭisañcikkhato abbhatthaṁ gacchati;
root_text.mn19:4-5.9: ‘paññānirodhiko vighātapakkhiko anibbānasaṁvattaniko’tipi me, bhikkhave, paṭisañcikkhato abbhatthaṁ gacchati.
root_text.mn19:4-5.10: So kho ahaṁ, bhikkhave, uppannuppannaṁ vihiṁsāvitakkaṁ pajahameva vinodameva byantameva naṁ akāsiṁ.
root_text.mn19:6.1: Yaññadeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bahulamanuvitakketi anuvicāreti, tathā tathā nati hoti cetaso.
root_text.mn19:6.2: Kāmavitakkañce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bahulamanuvitakketi anuvicāreti, pahāsi nekkhammavitakkaṁ, kāmavitakkaṁ bahulamakāsi, tassa taṁ kāmavitakkāya cittaṁ namati.
root_text.mn19:6.4: vihiṁsāvitakkañce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bahulamanuvitakketi anuvicāreti, pahāsi avihiṁsāvitakkaṁ, vihiṁsāvitakkaṁ bahulamakāsi, tassa taṁ vihiṁsāvitakkāya cittaṁ namati.
root_text.mn19:7.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, vassānaṁ pacchime māse saradasamaye kiṭṭhasambādhe gopālako gāvo rakkheyya.
root_text.mn19:7.2: So tā gāvo tato tato daṇḍena ākoṭeyya paṭikoṭeyya sannirundheyya sannivāreyya.
root_text.mn19:7.4: Passati hi so, bhikkhave, gopālako tatonidānaṁ vadhaṁ vā bandhanaṁ vā jāniṁ vā garahaṁ vā.
root_text.mn19:7.5: Evameva kho ahaṁ, bhikkhave, addasaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ādīnavaṁ okāraṁ saṅkilesaṁ, kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ nekkhamme ānisaṁsaṁ vodānapakkhaṁ.
root_text.mn19:8.1: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato uppajjati nekkhammavitakko.
root_text.mn19:8.4: So ca kho nevattabyābādhāya saṁvattati, na parabyābādhāya saṁvattati, na ubhayabyābādhāya saṁvattati, paññāvuddhiko avighātapakkhiko nibbānasaṁvattaniko’.
root_text.mn19:8.5: Rattiñcepi naṁ, bhikkhave, anuvitakkeyyaṁ anuvicāreyyaṁ, neva tatonidānaṁ bhayaṁ samanupassāmi.
root_text.mn19:8.6: Divasañcepi naṁ, bhikkhave, anuvitakkeyyaṁ anuvicāreyyaṁ, neva tatonidānaṁ bhayaṁ samanupassāmi.
root_text.mn19:8.7: Rattindivañcepi naṁ, bhikkhave, anuvitakkeyyaṁ anuvicāreyyaṁ, neva tatonidānaṁ bhayaṁ samanupassāmi.
root_text.mn19:8.8: Api ca kho me aticiraṁ anuvitakkayato anuvicārayato kāyo kilameyya.
root_text.mn19:8.11: So kho ahaṁ, bhikkhave, ajjhattameva cittaṁ saṇṭhapemi sannisādemi ekodiṁ karomi samādahāmi.
root_text.mn19:9-10.1: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato uppajjati abyāpādavitakko …pe…
root_text.mn19:9-10.5: So ca kho nevattabyābādhāya saṁvattati, na parabyābādhāya saṁvattati, na ubhayabyābādhāya saṁvattati, paññāvuddhiko avighātapakkhiko nibbānasaṁvattaniko’.
root_text.mn19:9-10.6: Rattiñcepi naṁ, bhikkhave, anuvitakkeyyaṁ anuvicāreyyaṁ, neva tatonidānaṁ bhayaṁ samanupassāmi.
root_text.mn19:9-10.7: Divasañcepi naṁ, bhikkhave, anuvitakkeyyaṁ anuvicāreyyaṁ, neva tatonidānaṁ bhayaṁ samanupassāmi.
root_text.mn19:9-10.8: Rattindivañcepi naṁ, bhikkhave, anuvitakkeyyaṁ anuvicāreyyaṁ, neva tatonidānaṁ bhayaṁ samanupassāmi.
root_text.mn19:9-10.9: Api ca kho me aticiraṁ anuvitakkayato anuvicārayato kāyo kilameyya.
root_text.mn19:9-10.12: So kho ahaṁ, bhikkhave, ajjhattameva cittaṁ saṇṭhapemi, sannisādemi, ekodiṁ karomi samādahāmi.
root_text.mn19:11.1: Yaññadeva, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bahulamanuvitakketi anuvicāreti, tathā tathā nati hoti cetaso.
root_text.mn19:11.2: Nekkhammavitakkañce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bahulamanuvitakketi anuvicāreti, pahāsi kāmavitakkaṁ, nekkhammavitakkaṁ bahulamakāsi, tassaṁ taṁ nekkhammavitakkāya cittaṁ namati.
root_text.mn19:11.4: avihiṁsāvitakkañce, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bahulamanuvitakketi anuvicāreti, pahāsi vihiṁsāvitakkaṁ, avihiṁsāvitakkaṁ bahulamakāsi, tassa taṁ avihiṁsāvitakkāya cittaṁ namati.
root_text.mn19:12.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gimhānaṁ pacchime māse sabbasassesu gāmantasambhatesu gopālako gāvo rakkheyya, tassa rukkhamūlagatassa vā abbhokāsagatassa vā satikaraṇīyameva hoti:
root_text.mn19:13.1: Āraddhaṁ kho pana me, bhikkhave, vīriyaṁ ahosi asallīnaṁ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṁ cittaṁ ekaggaṁ.
root_text.mn19:14.1: So kho ahaṁ, bhikkhave, vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsiṁ.
root_text.mn19:15.1: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsiṁ.
root_text.mn19:16.1: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca vihāsiṁ sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedesiṁ, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti, tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsiṁ.
root_text.mn19:17.1: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja vihāsiṁ.
root_text.mn19:18.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmesiṁ.
root_text.mn19:18.2: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarāmi. Seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarāmi.
root_text.mn19:19.1: Ayaṁ kho me, bhikkhave, rattiyā paṭhame yāme paṭhamā vijjā adhigatā;
root_text.mn19:19.2: avijjā vihatā vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato āloko uppanno; yathā taṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
root_text.mn19:20.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmesiṁ.
root_text.mn19:20.2: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passāmi cavamāne upapajjamāne …pe… ime vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā …pe… iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passāmi cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāmi.
root_text.mn19:21.1: Ayaṁ kho me, bhikkhave, rattiyā majjhime yāme dutiyā vijjā adhigatā;
root_text.mn19:21.2: avijjā vihatā vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato āloko uppanno; yathā taṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
root_text.mn19:22.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmesiṁ.
root_text.mn19:22.2: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ.
root_text.mn19:23.1: ‘Ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ abbhaññāsiṁ.
root_text.mn19:23.2: Tassa me evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccittha, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccittha, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccittha, vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ ahosi:
root_text.mn19:23.3: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti abbhaññāsiṁ.
root_text.mn19:24.1: Ayaṁ kho me, bhikkhave, rattiyā pacchime yāme tatiyā vijjā adhigatā;
root_text.mn19:24.2: avijjā vihatā vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato āloko uppanno; yathā taṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
root_text.mn19:25.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, araññe pavane mahantaṁ ninnaṁ pallalaṁ.
root_text.mn19:25.3: Tassa kocideva puriso uppajjeyya anatthakāmo ahitakāmo ayogakkhemakāmo.
root_text.mn19:25.4: So yvāssa maggo khemo sovatthiko pītigamanīyo taṁ maggaṁ pidaheyya, vivareyya kummaggaṁ, odaheyya okacaraṁ, ṭhapeyya okacārikaṁ.
root_text.mn19:25.5: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, mahāmigasaṅgho aparena samayena anayabyasanaṁ āpajjeyya.
root_text.mn19:25.6: Tasseva kho pana, bhikkhave, mahato migasaṅghassa kocideva puriso uppajjeyya atthakāmo hitakāmo yogakkhemakāmo.
root_text.mn19:25.7: So yvāssa maggo khemo sovatthiko pītigamanīyo taṁ maggaṁ vivareyya, pidaheyya kummaggaṁ, ūhaneyya okacaraṁ, nāseyya okacārikaṁ.
root_text.mn19:25.8: Evañhi so, bhikkhave, mahāmigasaṅgho aparena samayena vuddhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjeyya.
root_text.mn19:26.1: Upamā kho me ayaṁ, bhikkhave, katā atthassa viññāpanāya.
root_text.mn19:26.3: mahantaṁ ninnaṁ pallalanti kho, bhikkhave, kāmānametaṁ adhivacanaṁ.
root_text.mn19:26.5: Puriso anatthakāmo ahitakāmo ayogakkhemakāmoti kho, bhikkhave, mārassetaṁ pāpimato adhivacanaṁ.
root_text.mn19:26.6: Kummaggoti kho, bhikkhave, aṭṭhaṅgikassetaṁ micchāmaggassa adhivacanaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn19:26.7: micchādiṭṭhiyā micchāsaṅkappassa micchāvācāya micchākammantassa micchāājīvassa micchāvāyāmassa micchāsatiyā micchāsamādhissa.
root_text.mn19:26.10: Puriso atthakāmo hitakāmo yogakkhemakāmoti kho, bhikkhave, tathāgatassetaṁ adhivacanaṁ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
root_text.mn19:26.11: Khemo maggo sovatthiko pītigamanīyoti kho, bhikkhave, ariyassetaṁ aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa adhivacanaṁ, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn19:26.12: sammādiṭṭhiyā sammāsaṅkappassa sammāvācāya sammākammantassa sammāājīvassa sammāvāyāmassa sammāsatiyā sammāsamādhissa.
root_text.mn19:26.13: Iti kho, bhikkhave, vivaṭo mayā khemo maggo sovatthiko pītigamanīyo, pihito kummaggo, ūhato okacaro, nāsitā okacārikā.
root_text.mn19:27.1: Yaṁ, bhikkhave, satthārā karaṇīyaṁ sāvakānaṁ hitesinā anukampakena anukampaṁ upādāya, kataṁ vo taṁ mayā.
root_text.mn19:27.2: Etāni, bhikkhave, rukkhamūlāni, etāni suññāgārāni; jhāyatha, bhikkhave, mā pamādattha; mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha. Ayaṁ vo amhākaṁ anusāsanī”ti.
root_text.mn19:27.4: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn19:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn19:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn19:2.1: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
translation_text.mn19:2.2: ‘Why don’t I meditate by continually dividing my thoughts into two classes?’
translation_text.mn19:2.3: So I assigned sensual, malicious, and cruel thoughts
translation_text.mn19:2.5: And I assigned thoughts of renunciation, good will, and harmlessness
translation_text.mn19:3.1: Then, as I meditated—diligent, keen, and resolute—a sensual thought arose.
translation_text.mn19:3.3: ‘This sensual thought has arisen in me.
translation_text.mn19:3.4: It leads to hurting myself, hurting others, and hurting both. It blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment.’
translation_text.mn19:3.5: When I reflected that it leads to hurting myself, it went away.
translation_text.mn19:3.6: When I reflected that it leads to hurting others, it went away.
translation_text.mn19:3.7: When I reflected that it leads to hurting both, it went away.
translation_text.mn19:3.8: When I reflected that it blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment, it went away.
translation_text.mn19:3.9: So I gave up, got rid of, and eliminated any sensual thoughts that arose.
translation_text.mn19:4-5.1: Then, as I meditated—diligent, keen, and resolute—a malicious thought arose …
translation_text.mn19:4-5.4: ‘This cruel thought has arisen in me.
translation_text.mn19:4-5.5: It leads to hurting myself, hurting others, and hurting both. It blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment.’
translation_text.mn19:4-5.6: When I reflected that it leads to hurting myself …
translation_text.mn19:4-5.9: When I reflected that it blocks wisdom, it’s on the side of anguish, and it doesn’t lead to extinguishment, it went away.
translation_text.mn19:4-5.10: So I gave up, got rid of, and eliminated any cruel thoughts that arose.
translation_text.mn19:6.1: Whatever a mendicant frequently thinks about and considers becomes their heart’s inclination.
translation_text.mn19:6.2: If they often think about and consider sensual thoughts, they’ve given up the thought of renunciation to cultivate sensual thought. Their mind inclines to sensual thoughts.
translation_text.mn19:6.3: If they often think about and consider malicious thoughts … their mind inclines to malicious thoughts.
translation_text.mn19:6.4: If they often think about and consider cruel thoughts … their mind inclines to cruel thoughts.
translation_text.mn19:7.1: Suppose it’s the last month of the rainy season, when the crops grow closely together, and a cowherd must take care of the cattle.
translation_text.mn19:7.2: He’d tap and poke them with his staff on this side and that to keep them in check.
translation_text.mn19:7.4: For he sees that if they wander into the crops he could be executed, imprisoned, fined, or condemned.
translation_text.mn19:7.5: In the same way, I saw that unskillful qualities have the drawbacks of sordidness and corruption, and that skillful qualities have the benefit and cleansing power of renunciation.
translation_text.mn19:8.1: Then, as I meditated—diligent, keen, and resolute—a thought of renunciation arose.
translation_text.mn19:8.3: ‘This thought of renunciation has arisen in me.
translation_text.mn19:8.4: It doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both. It nourishes wisdom, it’s on the side of freedom from anguish, and it leads to extinguishment.’
translation_text.mn19:8.5: If I were to keep on thinking and considering this all night …
translation_text.mn19:8.7: all night and day, I see no danger that would come from that.
translation_text.mn19:8.8: Still, thinking and considering for too long would tire my body.
translation_text.mn19:8.9: And when the body is tired, the mind is stressed.
translation_text.mn19:8.10: And when the mind is stressed, it’s far from immersion.
translation_text.mn19:8.11: So I stilled, settled, unified, and immersed my mind internally.
translation_text.mn19:8.13: So that my mind would not be stressed.
translation_text.mn19:9-10.1: Then, as I meditated—diligent, keen, and resolute—a thought of good will arose …
translation_text.mn19:9-10.4: ‘This thought of harmlessness has arisen in me.
translation_text.mn19:9-10.5: It doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both. It nourishes wisdom, it’s on the side of freedom from anguish, and it leads to extinguishment.’
translation_text.mn19:9-10.6: If I were to keep on thinking and considering this all night …
translation_text.mn19:9-10.8: all night and day, I see no danger that would come from that.
translation_text.mn19:9-10.9: Still, thinking and considering for too long would tire my body.
translation_text.mn19:9-10.10: And when the body is tired, the mind is stressed.
translation_text.mn19:9-10.11: And when the mind is stressed, it’s far from immersion.
translation_text.mn19:9-10.12: So I stilled, settled, unified, and immersed my mind internally.
translation_text.mn19:9-10.14: So that my mind would not be stressed.
translation_text.mn19:11.1: Whatever a mendicant frequently thinks about and considers becomes their heart’s inclination.
translation_text.mn19:11.2: If they often think about and consider thoughts of renunciation, they’ve given up sensual thought to cultivate the thought of renunciation. Their mind inclines to thoughts of renunciation.
translation_text.mn19:11.3: If they often think about and consider thoughts of good will … their mind inclines to thoughts of good will.
translation_text.mn19:11.4: If they often think about and consider thoughts of harmlessness … their mind inclines to thoughts of harmlessness.
translation_text.mn19:12.1: Suppose it’s the last month of summer, when all the crops have been gathered within a village, and a cowherd must take care of the cattle. While at the root of a tree or in the open he need only be mindful that
translation_text.mn19:12.3: In the same way I needed only to be mindful that
translation_text.mn19:13.1: My energy was roused up and unflagging, my mindfulness was established and lucid, my body was tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind was immersed in samādhi.
translation_text.mn19:14.1: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn19:15.1: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn19:16.1: And with the fading away of rapture, I entered and remained in the third absorption, where I meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
translation_text.mn19:17.1: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
translation_text.mn19:18.1: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives.
translation_text.mn19:18.2: I recollected many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn19:19.1: This was the first knowledge, which I achieved in the first watch of the night.
translation_text.mn19:19.2: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
translation_text.mn19:20.1: When my mind had become immersed in samādhi like this, I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn19:20.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn19:21.1: This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night.
translation_text.mn19:21.2: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
translation_text.mn19:22.1: When my mind had become immersed in samādhi like this, I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn19:22.2: I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.'
translation_text.mn19:23.1: I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements.'
translation_text.mn19:23.2: Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
translation_text.mn19:23.3: I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.’
translation_text.mn19:24.1: This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night.
translation_text.mn19:24.2: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
translation_text.mn19:25.1: Suppose that in a forested wilderness there was an expanse of low-lying marshes,
translation_text.mn19:25.2: and a large herd of deer lived nearby.
translation_text.mn19:25.3: Then along comes a person who wants to harm, injure, and threaten them.
translation_text.mn19:25.4: They close off the safe, secure path that leads to happiness, and open the wrong path. There they plant domesticated male and female deer as decoys
translation_text.mn19:25.5: so that, in due course, that herd of deer would fall to ruin and disaster.
translation_text.mn19:25.6: Then along comes a person who wants to help keep the herd of deer safe.
translation_text.mn19:25.7: They open up the safe, secure path that leads to happiness, and close off the wrong path. They get rid of the decoys
translation_text.mn19:25.8: so that, in due course, that herd of deer would grow, increase, and mature.
translation_text.mn19:26.1: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
translation_text.mn19:26.2: And this is what it means.
translation_text.mn19:26.3: ‘An expanse of low-lying marshes’ is a term for sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn19:26.4: ‘A large herd of deer’ is a term for sentient beings.
translation_text.mn19:26.5: ‘A person who wants to harm, injure, and threaten them’ is a term for Māra the Wicked.
translation_text.mn19:26.6: ‘The wrong path’ is a term for the wrong eightfold path, that is,
translation_text.mn19:26.7: wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.
translation_text.mn19:26.8: ‘A domesticated male deer’ is a term for greed and relishing.
translation_text.mn19:26.9: ‘A domesticated female deer’ is a term for ignorance.
translation_text.mn19:26.10: ‘A person who wants to help keep the herd of deer safe’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
translation_text.mn19:26.11: ‘The safe, secure path that leads to happiness’ is a term for the noble eightfold path, that is:
translation_text.mn19:26.12: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
translation_text.mn19:26.13: So, mendicants, I have opened up the safe, secure path to happiness and closed off the wrong path. And I have got rid of the male and female decoys.
translation_text.mn19:27.1: Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.
translation_text.mn19:27.2: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”
translation_text.mn19:27.3: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn19:27.4: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

variant_text.mn19:3.9: pajahameva → pajjahameva (sya-all); pajahāmeva (pts1ed) | byantameva → byanteva (bj, pts1ed) | vinodameva → vinodanameva (sya-all); vinodemeva (pts1ed)

reference_text.mn19:3.1: cck12.218, dr12.209, ms9M_719, msdiv207, nya3, pts-vp-pli1.115, sya12.233
reference_text.mn19:8.1: cck12.220, ms9M_722, msdiv209, ndp9.155, nya8, pts-vp-pli1.116, sya12.235, vri12.165
